gw.api.filters

Class StandardQueryFilter

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.filters.StandardQueryFilter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IBeanFilter, IFilter, IQueryFilter

    public class StandardQueryFilter
extends java.lang.Object
implements IQueryFilter, IBeanFilter
    This class allows for the definition of new query filters. A query filter is used to modify a query that has already been constructed. One example of this is query-backed ListViews in the UI. In this case, a StandardQueryFilter can be used to define a filter on the ListView.

    A StandardQueryFilter is defind by implementing the StandardQueryFilter.QueryFilter interface. The implementation receives an instance of IQueryBuilder, to which it may add further restrictions. For example, imagine a query that returns all activities assigned to a user, and a requirement to define a filter to return only "open" activities assigned to that user. Assuming that the Activity entity is the root of the query, then one could define such a filter in the following way:

    new gw.api.filters.StandardQueryFilter( "Open Activities", \ q -> q.compare("Status", Equals, ActivityStatus.TC_OPEN))

    In the above example, the base query "q" is augmented to include only activities with the "open" status. Note that when a query returns a "view entity," that the query is still performed against the primary entity backing the view entity. Therefore, filters may use fields defined on the primary entity, even if those fields aren't defined on the view entity.

    A StandardQueryFilter can be used both on an IQueryResult as well as an IQuery. To apply to an IQueryResult, use the IQueryResult.addFilter(IQueryFilter) method. To apply to an IQuery, use the filterQuery(gw.api.database.IQuery) method directly.

    • Method Detail

      • applyFilter

        public boolean applyFilter(java.lang.Object obj)
        StandardQueryFilter also implements the IBeanFilter interface though the default implementation of applyFilter just throws an IllegalStateException. This makes it easy to create a standard filter that works as both a query and a bean filter - you can create a subclass of StandardQueryFilter that overrides applyFilter with whatever filter logic matches that used in the query filtering.
        Specified by:
        applyFilter in interface IBeanFilter
        Parameters:
        obj - the object to examine
        Returns:
        true if this object should be included, false if it should be filtered out

      • filterQuery

        public IQuery filterQuery(IQuery query)
        Applies this filter to the given query.
        Specified by:
        filterQuery in interface IQueryFilter
        Parameters:
        query - input
        Returns:
        the modified query, or a new copy of the query, with the additional restrictions added by this filter.
